title: The Bad Seed
creator: John, Jory; Oswald Pete
description: A naughty seed with a bad attitude, bad temper, and bad manners vows to change his life for the better, but his efforts are met with skepticism by his friends.
subject: SEL

title: The Bright Side
creator: Otis, Chad
description: "When an unhoused boy enters school, he runs afoul of rules and finds himself alone, but finds that he has imagination, resilience, and can define 'the bright side' for himself"
subject: Housing Insecurity
source:
Kirkus Reviews starred
SLJ express starred

title: The Day You Begin
creator: Woodson, Jacqueline; Lopez Rafael
description: How a new student feels like an outsider and learn everyone feels that way when the first start at a new school
subject: Individuality, friendship, and schools

title: Divorce is the Worst
creator: Higginbotham, Anastasia
description: Part of the Ordinary Terrible Things series, Divorce Is the Worst is a funny but frank picture book for kids whose parents are going through a divorce. In her iconic straightforward-but-sensitive way, author Anastasia Higginbotham sheds light on how hard it is for children to stay whole when their whole world, and the people in it, split apart.
subject: Divorce

title: Dreamers
creator: Morales, Yuyi
description: "An illustrated picture book autobiography in which award-winning author Yuyi Morales tells her own immigration story"--Provided by publisher.
subject: Immigration, Hispanic representation
source: Booklist starred, Horn Book Guide starred, Kirkus starred

title: Everybody Cooks Rice
creator: Dooley, Norah; Thornton Pete
description: A child is sent to find a younger brother at dinnertime and is introduced to a variety of cultures through encountering the many different ways rice is prepared at the different households visited.
subject: Culture practices

title: Fry Bread
creator: Maillard, Kevin Noble; Martinez-Neal, Juana
description: This portrayal of a modern Native American family, told in lively and powerful verse, uses fry bread as a metaphor for love, sharing, and honoring the old while embracing the new.
subject: Family and tradition
source: School Library Journal Starred, October 2019; Booklist starred, October, 2019; Pub Weekly, August 2019; Kirkus starred, July 2019; New York Times, November 2019; Horn Book, November 2019; Robert F. Sibert Informational Book Award Medal 2020

title: Geraldine
creator: Lilly, Elizabeth
description: Moving to a new school and struggling to meet friends, Geraldine befriends a fellow outcast and learns to be comfortable with who she is.
subject: Friendship and moving

title: Giraffes Can't Dance
creator: Andrae, Giles; Parker-Rees, Guy
description: Gerald is too clumsy to dance with all the other animals, until he finds the right music.
subject: Individuality
source: IRA Children’s Choice Award, IRA Teacher’s Choice Award

title: Hair Love
creator: Cherry, Matthew A.; Harrison, Vashti
description: A little girl’s dad steps in to help her arrange her wild hair into styles that allow her to be her natural, beautiful self.
subject: Father daughter relationship, Hairstyles

title: Hidden Figures
creator: Shetterly, Margot Lee; Freeman, Laura
description: Based on a true story of four black women who helped NASA launch men into space
subject: Women in STEAM

title: I Am Enough
creator: Byers, Grace; Bobo, Keturah A.
description: A story about loving who you are and being kind to one another.
subject: self-acceptance

title: Just Ask!: Be Different, Be Brave, Be You
creator: Sotomayor, Sonia; Lopez, Rafael
description: A story where friends with different abilities work together to build a community garden.
subject: Building a sense of community

title: Our Class is a Family
creator: Olsen, Shannon; Sonke, Sandie
description: Help build a sense of community within classrooms, help students feel safe, included, and loved.
subject: Class Community

title: Parker Looks Up
creator: Curry, Parker; Curry, Jessica; Jackson, Brittany
description: When Parker Curry came face-to-face with Amy Sherald's transcendent portrait of First Lady Michelle Obama ... She saw dynamic self-assurance. She saw truth and beauty. She saw a queen. But most importantly, Parker saw Her hopes. Her dreams, Her power. Her promise. Herself
subject: Role model, Inspiration

title: Something Happened In Our Town
creator: Celano, Marianne; Zivoin, Jennifer
description: "American Psychological Association." After discussing the police shooting of a local Black man with their families, Emma and Josh know how to treat a new student who looks and speaks differently than his classmates.
subject: Racial injustice, civil rights

title: Taco Falls Apart
creator: Miles, Brenda; Filipina, Monika
description: Taco Falls Apart gets kids thinking about how their thoughts shape feelings and behavior. Friendly and funny, this evidence-based science-informed book skillfully presents a fundamental concept of cognitive-behavior psychology in a way kids can understand -- how the interplay between thoughts, feelings, and behavior shape who we are and how we experience everything.
subject: SEL

title: The Truth About Dragons
creator: Leung, Julie; Cha, Hanna
description: In a mix of Eastern and Western mythologies, a mother tells her child about two forests inhabited by different, but equally enchanting dragons that coexist within the child's heart.
subject: Multicultural representation (Eastern and Western mythologies)
source: Kirkus Reviews, School Library Journal Starred

title: Two New Years
creator: Ho, Richard; Scurfield, Lynn
description: "For this multicultural family, inspired by the author's own, two New Years mean twice as much to celebrate! In the fall, Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year, offers an opportunity to bake challah, dip apples in honey, and lift voices in song. In the spring, Lunar New Year brings a chance to eat dumplings, watch dragon dances, and release glowing lanterns that light up the sky
subject: Multicultural representation (Chinese and Jewish)

title: We Belong to the Drum
creator: Lamouche, Sandra; Whitecalf, Azby
description: "Starting daycare, Nikosis, who grew up going to powwows with his family, where he was immersed in music, dance and the sound of the drum, feels like he doesn't fit in, until his mother and teachers use the drums to help him find connection and comfort"
subject: Indigenous representation
